trustfund:
TF027970-SDA COMPONENT OF THE MOZAMBIQUE
            HEALTH AND NUTRITION PROJECT,TF020815-HEALTH & NUTRITION PROJECT

abstracts.cdata!:
Ratings for the Health and Nutrition
            Project in Mozambique are as follows: overall outcome of the
            project was rated satisfactory, and the performance of the
            Bank and the Borrower were rated as satisfactory. Some of
            the lessons learned from the project are: 1) project
            simplicity and realistic objectives are important factors in
            project success, especially in an environment of great
            uncertainty and recognized weak capacity such as prevailed
            in Mozambique in the late 1980s. Project design also needs
            to be flexible to accommodate evolving country conditions;
            2) care needs to be taken when designing projects with more
            than one implementing sectoral ministry. Implementation is
            likely to become complicated; multiple implementing
            ministries should be avoided if feasible; 3) with the
            sectoral ministry clearly taking the lead in
            conceptualization and strategy development, donor
            coordination across the sector can be built around growing
            coordination in sub-sectors or sub-areas; 4) to effectively
            monitor implementation, clear and monitor able performance
            targets need to be set at appraisal; 5) continuity of
            technical assistance, often crucial to a project's
            success, can be achieved in the medium-term by ensuring
            repeated presence of the same advisors. This can also be
            achieved in the long-term with good communications access
            between visits; 6) e-mail communications between Ministry of
            Health (MOH)/ Gabinete de Coordinacao de Projectos de
            Investimento (GACOPI) and Washington-based Bank staff, which
            became available during implementation, greatly facilitated
            and sped up communication and decreased Health and Nutrition
            Project (HNP) communication costs.
